image.altText: Bill Shorten stands in front of a sign displaying an NDIS logo. He is wearing a black suit and tie.

items.synopsis: People with high-value NDIS plans are being bribed with fast food, kidnapped and having their funding drained by providers, a bombshell report says.

title.children: Boarding house residents 'kidnapped' for NDIS funding, Shorten suspects a nationwide problem

image.altText: Stan Grant speaks about not being seen as a human being image

items.synopsis: Although I try to shield myself from the racist abuse I'm frequently subjected to, the fact it is out there poisons the air I breathe. Now I have had enough – so on Monday night I will present Q+A, then walk away. For how long? I don't know, writes Stan Grant.

title.children: On Monday I'll present Q+A, then step away. Racism is violence and I have had enough

image.altText: Stan Grant gestures with both hands as he speaks at the National Press Club podium.

items.synopsis: Stan Grant accuses the ABC of "institutional failure", saying the organisation has failed to publicly defend him amid a storm of racist abuse which has forced him to step away from hosting Q+A.

title.children: Stan Grant steps away from Q+A citing 'relentless' racial abuse, accuses ABC of 'institutional failure'

image.altText: An elderly woman in a church

items.synopsis: The use of a taser against 95-year-old Clare Nowland raises concerns about restraint and the use of force in aged care facilities, advocates say, as homicide squad investigators are called in to investigate.

title.children: 'Not above the law': Police commissioner pledges robust review into elderly taser incident

image.altText: The top floor of a building shows fire damage to external walls and windows

items.synopsis: The man accused of lighting the fatal Loafers Lodge fire in New Zealand appears in the Wellington district court, charged with two counts of arson, as police confirm they have identified five bodies in the rubble.

title.children: Man accused of setting Wellington hostel fire that killed five people appears in court

image.altText: Doctor Ken Elliott smiles

items.synopsis: Australian doctor Kenneth Elliott is released "safe and well" after being kidnapped in Burkina Faso in 2016 by a group believed to have links to al Qaeda, with Foreign Minister Penny Wong saying the 88-year-old has been reunited with his family.

title.children: Australian doctor kidnapped by West African militant group released after seven years

image.altText: A woman with dark glasses and a shawl

items.synopsis: Stephanie Louise Bennett, 33, was caught using her mobile phone while driving and nominated Ashley Jenkinson as the driver.

title.children: Woman convicted of fraud for using dead Sea World helicopter pilot's name to avoid traffic fine

image.altText: Noel Pearson, wearing a brown hat, speaks at a lectern at a Garma Festival in north-east Arnhem Land.

items.synopsis: Noel Pearson says fellow campaigner Mick Gooda's fears that the Voice to Parliament is losing support are unfounded, while launching a tirade against the former Indigenous social justice commissioner.

title.children: Noel Pearson swipes fellow campaigner Mick Gooda, who says Voice to Parliament is losing support

image.altText: View of small island from plane

items.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology warns of a possible tsunami after a magnitude-7.7 earthquake south-east of the Loyalty Islands in New Caledonia.

title.children: Earthquake off New Caledonia triggers tsunami warning for Lord Howe Island

image.altText: Tyson Denny at a park with two dogs.

items.synopsis: An off-road motorbike rider, who killed a Perth man on a suburban pathway he was not entitled to be on, is jailed.

title.children: Speeding motorbike rider jailed for 'almost inevitable' shared path crash that killed Perth man

image.altText: Pile of rubbish at a house, including old mattresses, bikes, boxes and bottles.

items.synopsis: International students say they are being blamed for the rental crisis, but they're also facing housing stress and exploitation. Their horror stories are being shared back home and other students are now ditching plans to come to Australia.

title.children: Facing housing horrors, international students say they were misled about the cost of living in Australia

image.altText: A woman with curly hair and glasses smiling and cuddling a dog.

items.synopsis: Morgan says she often has to explain her condition to support workers and teachers, so she's using social media to highlight how it affects everyday life for those living with the rare syndrome.

title.children: 'We just want to make friends': Why Morgan is raising awareness about a rare genetic condition

image.altText: young man smiling, wearing blackglasses and maroon top on a sunny day

items.synopsis: Mitchell Taylor was in and out of a group home for 10 years. His parents became concerned when he began begging not to go.

title.children: Mitchell was prescribed medication for repeated seizures. His parents suspect his group home used it to control him

image.altText: The dome in Hiroshima

items.synopsis: The leaders of the world's wealthiest democracies are meeting in Hiroshima, the site of the world's first nuclear attack, as they discuss the dangers of Russia and China.

title.children: Japan is hosting this year's G7 and its setting is a symbolic warning about the dangers of Putin's nuclear threats

image.altText: A man walking through a glass door.

items.synopsis: The ABC will argue the broadcast of a National Press Club address by Brittany Higgins was a "fair report of proceedings of public concern" and also rely on defences of qualified privilege and innocent dissemination in its case.

title.children: ABC files defence in defamation case brought by Bruce Lehrmann

image.altText: An elderly woman leans in to blow out candles on her birthday cake

items.synopsis: The son of Gloria Shea, who suffered from emphysema and was reliant on life support equipment when the power cut off to her Dubbo home, wants energy companies to improve their safety measures.

title.children: Family seeks urgent changes to home life support after great-grandmother dies during power cut

image.altText: police stand at the front of house

items.synopsis: A woman who appears to be the mother has presented herself to officers after the discovery of a newborn baby in Blacktown last month.

title.children: DNA testing underway to identify mother of newborn baby abandoned in Western Sydney

image.altText: Ukrainian soldier bends over and covers ears as a mortar is fired.

items.synopsis: The Ukrainian military and Russia's Wagner private army report further Russian retreats around the city of Bakhmut, as Kyiv presses on with its biggest advance for six months ahead of a planned counter-offensive.

title.children: Ukraine says it is repelling Russian attacks in Bakhmut, as US says it over-valued weapons aid

image.altText: Graham Rowe 64yo jobseeker

items.synopsis: Rising unemployment and falling job vacancies may be signalling a turning point in Australia's labour market, economists say.

title.children: Unemployment has been around the lowest level in 50 years but Graham still can't find work

image.altText: A tight head shot of Kempton Cowan wearing a face mask and spectacles.

items.synopsis: Kempton Cowan, the former head of one of Western Australia's largest hospitals, is facing a jail term after pleading guilty to accessing, soliciting, and transmitting child abuse material.

title.children: Former Perth hospital chief admits guilt over videos of girls being sexually abused

image.altText: A person is bound with handcuffs behind their back, with paint covering their hands. Two police lead her away

items.synopsis: In the wake of Extinction Rebellion demonstrations in the heart of Adelaide this week, proposed changes to a law relating to public protest are generating a chorus of opposition from unions and human rights groups.

title.children: Boost to SA public obstruction fine — from $750 to $50,000 — slammed by human rights groups

image.altText: Vincent Lingiari addresses media

items.synopsis: 'No' campaign leaders Warren Mundine and Jacinta Nampijinpa Price have both claimed Indigenous land rights activist Vincent Lingiari's grandson opposed the Voice. Was that actually correct?

title.children: 'I'm not his grandson': How the 'No' campaign misled using Vincent Lingiari's name

image.altText: A composite image of Russian scientists Anatoly Maslov, Alexandr Shiplyuk and Valery Zvegintsev looking towards the camera

items.synopsis: Anatoly Maslov, Alexandr Shiplyuk and Valery Zvegintsev face "very serious accusations" of state treason, the Kremlin says. Here's what we know about the hypersonic missile scientists.

title.children: Who are the three Russian scientists accused of state treason?

image.altText: An oval shaped island with white sand beaches, greenery and coral reefs surrounding.

items.synopsis: The Brisbane Magistrates Court has been told the Heron Island Resort chef offered to make a nut-free dessert, then used a pre-packaged cake that contained almonds and possibly other nuts.

title.children: Barrier Reef island resort fined for serving dessert containing nuts to allergic teenager

image.altText: A house with a veranda and a for lease sign outside, leaning against wall

items.synopsis: If a rent increase is on the cards, here's how you can get on top of it without straining your relationship with the landlord.

title.children: Renters are successfully negotiating their rental increase down — here's how they do it

image.altText: Man on beach with sombre expression

items.synopsis: The full details of the child sexual abuse charges issued to south-west Victorian Koori Court elder Robert 'Locky' Charles Eccles have been released for the first time as he appeared in court today.

title.children: Former Koori Court elder and Senior Citizen of the Year charged with historic child abuse offences

image.altText: A shattered windscreen of a bus with no windows and a police officer looking in

items.synopsis: The Eynesbury community rallies around the children and family caught up in the horror Exford Primary School bus crash, raising thousands of dollars to help children with serious injuries return to classrooms.

title.children: An after-school tragedy met with a 'heartwarming' display

image.altText: Volunteer Week Amber & Alfie

items.synopsis: Australians are increasingly bypassing volunteering at established organisations such as charities or sporting groups, instead opting for more flexible or informal arrangements, a survey finds.

title.children: 'Making a meal' for social media call-outs on the increase as people pivot from traditional volunteering

image.altText: An aerial photo showing a group of buildings and a grassed oval.

items.synopsis: Claims of sexual misconduct and excessive use of force by custodial officers against youth detainees at Banksia Hill Detention Centre are tabled in the WA parliament.

title.children: Girl allegedly hit in head with chairs and hogtied at Banksia Hill, as dozens of complaints against staff revealed

image.altText: wornout steel post with numbers marking flood readings, next to a brown river

items.synopsis: Lismore, the epicentre of Australia's most expensive natural disaster, was not prioritised in this week's federal announcement of $236 million to fund flood warning upgrades.

title.children: Why Australia's most flood-prone postcode isn't a priority for improved flood warning systems

image.altText: The tails of Qantas planes showing the flying kangaroo pass each other at Sydney Airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas will boost the number of international flights later this year, and ASX rises.

title.children: Qantas to boost international flights as ASX rises

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Business reporter Emilia Terzon here with some interesting late Friday afternoon news about the mortgage market. Westpac has told brokers that it's going to let some borrowers refinance over to the big four bank, even if they fail standard stress tests on their new loans. Typically, banks will assess a borrower's finances to make sure they could still afford to pay it if interest rates rose, typically by 3 per cent in line with APRA guidelines. Westpac has told its brokers that now: If a customer is unable to meet serviceability under the standard assessment criteria, a modified Serviceability Assessment Rate (SAR) may be applied as a credit exception to new and existing consumer mortgage commitments. Streamline Refinance is only available to customers who meet eligibility criteria and have a proven track record of servicing their existing loan commitments. The standard floor rate will continue to apply. There is a lot of provisos, however. People can't refinance to Westpac, and its subsidaries St George, Bank of Melbourne and BankSA, under this dropped serviceability if their repayments will be higher than their old loan. They also need a credit score over 650, and no arrears or hardship in the last 12 months. This get out of jail free card also can't be given to people on a guarantor loan or those with lenders mortgage insurance, which would be cutting out a whole lot of first home buyers. Homeloan comparison website RateCity is supporting the deal. "The current buffer of 3 percentage points helps ensure new borrowers don’t take out excessive debts compared to their incomes," it says in a statement. "However, the test is locking some existing borrowers into mortgage prison." RateCity cited data that showed just 3.1 per cent of new loans taken out in December quarter didn't meet serviceability guidelines set by APRA. APRA boosted the serviceability guideline buffer in 2021. "RateCity.com.au believes Australia’s banking regulator, APRA, should consider officially lowering the serviceability buffer for refinancers," the website added. It is an interesting tactic from a bank, in a time when we know that the number of new home loans being taken out is lower than it was during the pandemic boom. The deal also only applies if you're an external customer, but not if you're a current Westpac customer looking to internally refinance within the bank's subsidiaries. What do you think? Is this good policy from the bank, the regulators and the market? Send us a comment here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Westpac slashes servicibility to steal mortgage prisoners

children.content: Business reporter Emilia Terzon here with some interesting late Friday afternoon news about the mortgage market.
Westpac has told brokers that it's going to let some borrowers refinance over to the big four bank, even if they fail standard stress tests on their new loans.
Typically, banks will assess a borrower's finances to make sure they could still afford to pay it if interest rates rose,
typically by 3 per cent in line with APRA
guidelines.
Westpac has told its brokers that now:

If a customer is unable to meet serviceability under the standard assessment criteria, a modified Serviceability Assessment Rate (SAR) may be applied as a credit exception to new and existing consumer mortgage commitments.

Streamline Refinance is only available to customers who meet eligibility criteria and have a proven track record of servicing their existing loan commitments. The standard floor rate will continue to apply.
There is a lot of provisos, however.
People can't refinance to Westpac, and its subsidaries St George, Bank of Melbourne and BankSA, under this dropped serviceability if their repayments will be higher than their old loan.
They also need a credit score over 650, and no arrears or hardship in the last 12 months.
This get out of jail free card also can't be given to people on a guarantor loan or those with lenders mortgage insurance, which would be cutting out a whole lot of first home buyers.
Homeloan comparison website RateCity is supporting the deal.
"The current buffer of 3 percentage points helps ensure new borrowers don’t take out excessive debts compared to their incomes," it says in a statement.
"However, the test is locking some existing borrowers into mortgage prison."
RateCity cited data that showed just 3.1 per cent of new loans taken out in December quarter didn't meet serviceability guidelines set by APRA.
APRA boosted the serviceability guideline buffer in 2021
"RateCity.com.au believes Australia’s banking regulator, APRA, should consider officially lowering the serviceability buffer for refinancers," the website added.
It is an interesting tactic from a bank, in a time when we know that the number of new home loans being taken out is lower than it was during the pandemic boom.
The deal also only applies if you're an external customer, but not if you're a current Westpac customer looking to internally refinance within the bank's subsidiaries.
What do you think? Is this good policy from the bank, the regulators and the market? Send us a comment here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Austal USA, the company's North American subsidiary, has won an initial $US114 million ($172 million) contract for detail design of the new Auxiliary General Ocean Surveillance Ship T-AGOS 25 Class for the US Navy. The contract includes options for the detail design and construction of up to seven of the ships which, if the US Navy exercises them, would bring the total value of the contract to $US3.195 billion ($4.8 billion). The ships are primarily used for anti-submarine warfare, using towed array sonar. The ASX-listed company originally specialised in aluminium hulled vessels, such as littoral combat and fast transport ships for the US Navy, but has since expanded into more conventional steel hulls. "The T-AGOS contract is a clear acknowledgment of Austal's capabilities in steel naval shipbuilding, that includes the Navy's Towing, Salvage and Rescue (T-ATS) ships, an Auxiliary Floating Drydock Medium (AFDM), and the US Coast Guards' Offshore Patrol Cutters," said the company's CEO Paddy Gregg. "These four steel naval shipbuilding projects, and our continuing successful delivery of the Independence-variant Littoral Combat Ship and Spearhead-class Expeditionary Fast Transport programs, are positioning Austal USA exceptionally well to meet the growing demands of the US Navy and Coast Guard." If successful, the company will build the ships at its facility in Mobile, Alabama. The company's shares were up 25.4% to $2.00 near the end of trade today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Perth-based shipbuilder Austal wins potential $4.8 billion US defence contract

children.content: Austal USA
, the company's North American subsidiary, has won
an initial $US114 million ($172 million) contract for detail design of the new Auxiliary General Ocean Surveillance Ship T-AGOS 25 Class
for the US Navy.
The contract includes
options for the detail design and construction of up to seven of the ships
which, if the US Navy exercises them,
would bring the total value of the contract to $US3.195 billion ($4.8 billion)
The ships are primarily used for anti-submarine warfare, using towed array sonar.
The ASX-listed company originally specialised in aluminium hulled vessels, such as littoral combat and fast transport ships for the US Navy, but has since expanded into more conventional steel hulls.

"The T-AGOS contract is a clear acknowledgment of Austal's capabilities in steel naval shipbuilding, that includes the Navy's Towing, Salvage and Rescue (T-ATS) ships, an Auxiliary Floating Drydock Medium (AFDM), and the US Coast Guards' Offshore Patrol Cutters," said the company's CEO Paddy Gregg.

"These four steel naval shipbuilding projects, and our continuing successful delivery of the Independence-variant Littoral Combat Ship and Spearhead-class Expeditionary Fast Transport programs, are positioning Austal USA exceptionally well to meet the growing demands of the US Navy and Coast Guard."
If successful,
the company will build the ships at its facility in Mobile, Alabama
The company's
shares were up 25.4% to $2.00
near the end of trade today.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas says it will adding extra flights to its international schedule, with more flights, more aircraft and new routes later this year. It says the network changes will see its international capacity grow to around 100% of pre-COVID levels by March 2024 (up from 44% a year ago, and 84% today). Here are some of the changes coming: More flights to key destinations including Tokyo, Los Angeles and New York Frequency between Australia and Japan to double with four daily flights to Tokyo Two new international routes to launch from Brisbane Two Airbus A330s to be leased from Finnair to meet demand It says an extra 300 workers (pilots and cabin crew) will be needed by the end of the year to support the extra flying. However, some of the extra flying will be achieved by an arrangement with Finnair (Finland's flag carrier and largest airline) to operate two Airbus A330 aircraft on two Qantas routes. Outgoing Qantas CEO Alan Joyce says the rebound in demand for international travel since borders reopened has been "incredibly strong." “While airlines globally are working to restore capacity to meet demand, there is still a mismatch between supply and demand for international flying," he said. "But with more of our aircraft back in the air, new 787s joining our fleet and our contract with Finnair, we’ve got more seats for our customers and more opportunity for Qantas crew as we increase our own flying. “We know our customers are looking for great value and this additional capacity will also put downward pressure on fares."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas boosting the number of its international flights (with help from Finnair pilots)

children.content: Qantas says it will adding extra flights to its international schedule, with more flights, more aircraft and new routes later this year.
It says the network changes will see its international capacity grow to around 100% of pre-COVID levels by March 2024 (up from 44% a year ago, and 84% today).
Here are some of the changes coming:
More flights to key destinations including Tokyo, Los Angeles and New York
Frequency between Australia and Japan to double with four daily flights to Tokyo
Two new international routes to launch from Brisbane
Two Airbus A330s to be leased from Finnair to meet demand
It says an extra 300 workers (pilots and cabin crew) will be needed by the end of the year to support the extra flying.
However, some of the extra flying will be achieved by an arrangement with Finnair (Finland's flag carrier and largest airline) to operate two Airbus A330 aircraft on two Qantas routes.
Outgoing Qantas CEO Alan Joyce says the rebound in demand for international travel since borders reopened has been "incredibly strong."
“While airlines globally are working to restore capacity to meet demand, there is still a mismatch between supply and demand for international flying," he said.

"But with more of our aircraft back in the air, new 787s joining our fleet and our contract with Finnair, we’ve got more seats for our customers and more opportunity for Qantas crew as we increase our own flying.
“We know our customers are looking for great value and this additional capacity will also put downward pressure on fares."

image.altText: A drone circles above a whale.

items.synopsis: It's the perfect time to spot the mammals from locations along WA's south coast — and to send the drone up. But there are certain rules that must be followed.

title.children: Want to use your drone during the WA whale migration? Here's what you should know

image.altText: Indigenous dancers in traditional costume dance on a beach

items.synopsis: One of the most remote Indigenous towns in Australia showcases its rich culture to its first foreign visitors, with leaders excited about the economic and social impact of tourism.

title.children: Isolated Aboriginal community thrilled to welcome first international tourists

image.altText: An excited football fan takes a selfie next to a smiling footballer from his team after a big win.

items.synopsis: Football drama abounds, with Sheffield Wednesday mounting a never-been-done-before comeback to win their League One play-off semifinal, while West Ham players families are attacked in the stands after a Europa Conference League semifinal win.

title.children: History made in English football playoff as Sheffield Wednesday produce comeback for the ages
